conclusion: The conductor rod cd is horizontally suspended by two insulating strings and remains stationary in a uniform magnetic field.
The positive direction of the x-axis is horizontally to the right, the positive direction of the y-axis is vertically upward, and the positive direction of the z-axis is coming out of the page.
The rod is along the positive x-axis.
The mass of the rod is m=10g=0.01kg, and its length is L=50cm=0.50m.
The gravitational acceleration is g=10m/s².
The magnetic field is in the negative z-direction, so B1 = -B1 k, with B1 = 1.0T.
The tension in the strings is zero.

The forces acting on the rod are the gravitational force Fg, the magnetic force Fm1, and the tension in the strings T1. Since the rod is in equilibrium and the tension is zero, the net force is zero: Fg + Fm1 + T1 = 0, Fg + Fm1 + 0 = 0, Fm1 = -Fg.
The gravitational force is Fg = mg = mg(-j) = -mgj, since the positive y-axis is upward.
The magnetic force is Fm1 = -(-mgj) = mgj. This means the magnetic force is vertically upward.
The magnetic force on a current-carrying conductor is given by Fm = I L × B.
Let I1 be the current in the rod cd.
The rod is along the positive x-axis, with length L.
Assume the current flows from c to d. Then the direction of the current is along the positive x-axis, so L = Li.
Fm1 = I1 (Li) × (-B1k) = -I1 L B1 (i × k).
We know that i × k = -j.
Fm1 = -I1 L B1 (-j) = I1 L B1 j.
Comparing this with Fm1 = mgj, we have I1 L B1 j = mgj.
This gives I1 L B1 = mg.
Since I1 is the magnitude of the current, I1 ≥ 0.
